title: 108_s1932
content: The Act may be cited as the "Artists' Rights and Theft Prevention Act of 2004" or the "ART Act". Congressional findings are also included in the Act. Congress finds that intellectual property is crucial for innovation and economic development, deserving protection under the law. Music, film, software, and other forms of intellectual property are vital sectors of the US economy. The industries accounted for over 5% of the US GDP in 2001, nearly 6% of US employment, and led in foreign sales and exports. Congress passed the "No Electronic Theft (NET) Act" to address illegal reproduction and distribution of copyrighted materials online. President Clinton signed the "No Electronic Theft (NET) Act" in 1997 to strengthen copyright and trademark laws for prosecuting individuals involved in large-scale illegal reproduction or distribution of copyrighted works. The Act's economic harm requirement makes investigations resource-intensive and challenging, aiming for broader deterrence and easier prosecution. The distribution of prerelease commercial works can cause significant economic harm, especially through the use of camcorders in movie theaters to make illegal copies of films. Online theft of copyrighted works remains a challenge for enforcement. Online theft of music, film, software, and intellectual property is on the rise, causing a significant negative impact on the US economy. Sales in the music industry dropped by almost 31 percent from 2000 to 2003. Federal legislation is needed to combat online theft and its economic consequences. Article 1, section 8 of the United States Constitution grants Congress the power to protect the rights of authors and inventors for their creations. This includes regulating commerce with foreign nations and among states. The music, film, software, and other intellectual property industries are crucial for the US economy. The United States economy is well-documented and significant. Theft and unauthorized distribution of intellectual property occur regularly across state and international lines. Criminal penalties for unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a movie theater are outlined in Section 3. Section 2319B of Title 18, US Code, criminalizes unauthorized recording of movies in theaters with penalties of up to 3 years imprisonment and fines. Section 2319B of Title 18, US Code, imposes penalties for unauthorized recording of movies in theaters, including imprisonment for up to 6 years, fines, and forfeiture of unauthorized copies and equipment used in the offense. This section does not restrict authorized activities. (c) Authorized Activities.--This section allows for lawful investigative, protective, or intelligence activities by authorized personnel at various levels of government or under contract. Immunity for theaters is granted to detain individuals involved in unauthorized recording of movies in a reasonable manner. The licensor has the authority to detain and question individuals suspected of violating the section without liability. Victims of the offense are allowed to submit a victim impact statement during the presentence report preparation. Victims of the offense can submit a victim impact statement to the probation officer, detailing the injury, loss, and economic impact suffered. The statement should include information about producers, sellers, and holders of intellectual property rights affected by the offense. In this section, definitions for terms related to intellectual property rights are provided, including those for audiovisual work, copy, copyright owner, motion picture, motion picture exhibition facility, and transmit. The term 'audiovisual recording device' is also defined as any technology capable of recording audiovisual content. The curr_chunk discusses the prohibition of using technology to record or transmit copyrighted audiovisual works. It also includes a clerical amendment to the table of sections in the United States Code. The curr_chunk introduces a new section on unauthorized recording of motion pictures in a motion picture exhibition facility and provides a definition for "motion picture exhibition facility." Additionally, it includes a provision on criminal infringement of a work being prepared for commercial distribution. The curr_chunk amends Section 506(a) of title 17, United States Code, regarding criminal infringement of copyright for commercial gain through reproduction or distribution of copyrighted works. The curr_chunk specifies that willful infringement of copyright for commercial gain includes distributing copyrighted works intended for commercial distribution on a computer network accessible to the public. Evidence of reproduction or distribution alone is not enough to establish willful infringement. The definition of 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' in copyright law includes computer programs, musical works, motion pictures, and sound recordings that have not been commercially distributed but are expected to be. Willful infringement for commercial gain involves distributing such works on a public computer network. The amendment to Section 2319 of title 18, United States Code, addresses unauthorized distribution of works like motion pictures that have been made available in theaters but not for sale to the public in a format for home viewing. Amendment to Section 2319 of title 18, United States Code includes changes to criminal penalties for copyright infringement. Amendment to Section 2319 of title 18, United States Code increases penalties for copyright infringement, including imprisonment up to 10 years and fines. The amendment to Section 2319 of title 18, United States Code increases penalties for copyright infringement, including imprisonment up to 10 years, fines, or both for second or subsequent offenses. The term 'financial gain' is defined as in section 101 of title 17, and 'work being prepared for commercial' is also clarified. The term 'work being prepared for commercial distribution' is defined in section 506(a) of title 17. Civil remedies are available for infringement of a work being prepared for commercial distribution under section 5. Preregistration procedures for works being prepared for commercial distribution will be established by the Register of Copyrights within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. This will allow preregistration for works in specific classes determined by the Register. The Register of Copyrights will establish preregistration procedures for works with a history of infringement before authorized distribution. Applicants must submit an application, deposit, and fee within 3 months of first publication. Failure to do so will result in dismissal of infringement actions without statutory damages or attorney fees. The Register of Copyrights will establish preregistration procedures for works with a history of infringement before authorized distribution. Failure to submit the required items to the Copyright Office within 3 months of first publication or 1 month after learning of infringement will result in dismissal of infringement actions without statutory damages or attorney fees. Section 411(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include "preregistration or" before "shall be instituted until". Section 412 of title 17, United States Code, is excluded. Section 412 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include an action for infringement of a copyright of a work that has been preregistered under section 408(f) before the commencement of the infringement. Federal sentencing guidelines are addressed in Section 6. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and potentially amend sentencing guidelines for intellectual property crimes within 180 days of this Act. This includes offenses under specific sections of title 17 and title 18 of the United States Code. The United States Sentencing Commission may amend Federal sentencing guidelines to deter intellectual property rights violations. The United States Sentencing Commission may amend Federal sentencing guidelines to address intellectual property rights crimes, including determining sentencing enhancements for unauthorized display, performance, publication, reproduction, or distribution of copyrighted works. Additionally, they will assess if the current guidelines on "uploading" are sufficient to address related losses. The United States Sentencing Commission is evaluating if sentencing guidelines adequately address losses from unauthorized distribution of copyrighted works over the Internet, especially when the number of reproductions or distributions is unknown. Authorization of appropriations of $5,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2005-2009 to prosecute violations of intellectual property rights under specific sections of the United States Code.
